keyTakeAways: The Glória funicular crash in Lisbon on 3 September 2025 resulted in 16 deaths and 20 injuries, including 11 foreigners and three British nationals.
A defective underground cable, never certified for passenger transport and acquired in 2022, acted as a counterweight and broke during the crash, contributing to the derailed accident.
The cable was not tested before installation, and there was a failure in oversight by Carris engineers and outsourced maintenance teams.
The emergency brake system failed to activate properly and had never been tested in advance, despite the driver’s correct attempt to apply it.
Carris dismissed its head of maintenance for funiculars and trams following the incident, indicating internal accountability.
The preliminary report notes the information is incomplete and does not assign guilt or responsibility to any individual or organization.
The investigation highlights a systemic failure in maintenance, certification, and safety testing, with recommendations for improved safety management systems and end-to-end oversight.
Lisbon’s historic funiculars are currently exempt from legal oversight, a loophole now being closed by the report’s recommendations.
All Lisbon cable cars are currently out of service until safety checks are completed, and all braking systems must be reviewed to ensure functionality in cable failure scenarios.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A preliminary report into a fatal funicular crash in Lisbon on 3 September 2025 reveals a series of critical safety failures, including the use of a defective underground cable that was never certified for passenger transport and had not been tested before installation. The cable, acquired in 2022 by Carris, the operator of Lisbon’s public transport, failed under load, causing the 140-year-old Glória funicular to derail and crash into a building, killing 16 people and injuring 20. The report highlights significant lapses in oversight, maintenance, and testing, with the emergency brake system also failing to function. Carris has dismissed its head of maintenance, and all cable cars in Lisbon are currently out of service pending safety checks. The investigation is ongoing, with the full report expected in 11 months, and key recommendations include implementing a new safety management system in line with European best practice and closing a legal loophole allowing funiculars to be exempt from supervision.
title: Lisbon funicular crash initial report reveals litany of failings
